evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures better explained the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 directly document communication and coordination interactions and failures among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of observable communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the hist_pair_engine_t2_interim phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies procedural deviation rather than communication failure.
The documented actions and statements from the tug instructor and trainee accurately reflect the event.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but ignored, suggesting a communication breakdown rather than procedural deviation.
If mechanical or environmental factors caused the pushback error instead of operator action.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the aircraft exceeding the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H8 supports this by describing inadequate communication signals, favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness and possible unreported environmental or mechanical factors

Communication failures are inferred from lack of warnings and continuation beyond TRP

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA's operational procedures and hist_pair_engine_t2_interim data, indicating a relevant and characteristic anomaly.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and procedures are correctly understood and applied as per Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA operational standards.
The trainee and instructor's qualifications and training are sufficient to identify procedural deviations.
defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, or if mechanical faults were detected in the tug or aircraft controls, this would challenge the procedural deviation interpretation.
If communication breakdown evidence was stronger, indicating crew coordination failure rather than procedural non-compliance.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, and H9 directly describe the procedural deviation in pushback execution, showing the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite known procedures and training, supporting the claim that the deviation aligns with key features of operational procedures. Discriminators favor procedural deviation over environmental or mechanical causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of environmental marking deficiency or mechanical failure; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not physically present or reachable when needed

node.statement: Crew members were not physically present or reachable when needed

assumptions: Lack of warning from wingman or headset operator implies they were not reachable or physically present when needed.
defeaters: If evidence showed that crew members were physically present and actively communicating or reachable at the time, this would change the assessment.
If the collision was caused by mechanical failure or environmental factors rather than communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H8 directly states that the tug instructor did not receive any warning from other crew members, indicating they were not reachable or physically present to prevent the incident, supporting the claim of crew unavailability.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether lack of warning equates to physical absence or just failure to communicate effectively.

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine markings for signs of wear, damage, or obstruction that would reduce their effectiveness

node.statement: Scheduled communication times or protocols were not adhered to by crew members

defeaters: If evidence showed that communication protocols were followed but other factors caused the incident
If the visual signals were considered sufficient and warnings were given but ignored

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Operational conditions include the actual pushback scenario with crew focus and positioning.
defeaters: If additional evidence showed clear, unambiguous, and consistently visible environmental markings and signals effectively used by crew during pushback, this would change the assessment.

node.statement: Relevant environmental markings are physically present at the site

No evidence indicates markings were missing or physically deficient.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were missing, obscured, or physically damaged, or if crew explicitly reported inability to see markings, this would support environmental marking deficiency.
If the tug driver or crew reported confusion or lack of awareness due to missing or unclear markings.

outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about physical condition or visibility of markings; reliance on indirect inference from clearance and incident details.

No other evidence indicates obscured or damaged markings.
defeaters: If evidence showed obscured, damaged, or missing environmental markings or TRP ground markings, or if the blast barrier was not clearly marked or visible.

He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct evidence about the condition or visibility of environmental markings; reliance on indirect inference from communication and procedural descriptions.

He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

node.statement: Availability of trained ground personnel to assist with pushback

defeaters: If evidence showed lack of trained personnel or communication failure, or environmental factors caused the deviation, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4, H8, and H9 directly describe the availability and actions of trained ground personnel during pushback, showing the trainee and instructor roles and communication, supporting the claim of availability of trained ground personnel.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence is direct and detailed.
